content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would approach this repeated game strategically. In this game, the payoff matrix can be represented as follows:

|   | R     | B     |
|---|---|---|
| R  | 45,45 | 0,42  |
| B  | 42,0  | 12,12 |

Notice that choosing the same action (R or B) in every round results in a lower payoff compared to alternating choices. For instance, if both players consistently pick R, they will earn 45$ each round but only for 75 rounds out of the total 150 possible rounds (since the other player could potentially pick B). On the other hand, if both players alternate between R and B, they can maximize their earnings.

In order to maximize my payoff, I would try to find a strategy that incentivizes the opponent to choose B when I choose R and vice versa. One such strategy is the Tit-for-Tat strategy, where I start by choosing R on the first round, then copy the opponent's previous move in the subsequent rounds. This way, if my opponent starts with R, I will also stick with R to earn 45$, but if they choose B initially, I will switch to B to punish them and make them switch back when I do so.

However, since the game is repeated multiple times, the opponent might adopt a similar strategy, leading to an alternation of choices. In this case, by following Tit-for-Tat, my expected payoff would be 28.5$ per round (the average of 45$, 12$, and 0$).

Given that the game has 75 rounds, I can expect to earn approximately 75 * 28.5 = $2137.5 over the entire course of the game if the opponent follows a similar strategy. While it might be tempting to pick B on the first round to punish my opponent for potentially choosing B later in the game, sticking with R initially and following Tit-for-Tat is likely to result in a higher overall payoff.

In summary, I would choose {R} as my initial move and follow a Tit-for-Tat strategy throughout the game.
